facts.text: Petitioners Amar Singh and four others are displaced persons who owned land in Chak No. 159-RB, Tahsil Jaranwala, District Lyallpur in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: All these five are displaced persons who owned land in the number-suburban village of Chak. No. 159-RB, Tahsil Jaranwala, District Lyallpur in Pakistan.

facts.text: Petitioners were co-sharers in a joint khata owned by some evacuees in village Sultanwind, a suburb of Amritsar in East Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: They were also companysharers in a joint khata owned by some evacuees in village Sultanwind, a suburb of Amritsar in East Punjab.

facts.text: Petitioners were temporarily allotted agricultural land in Sultanwind.

anchor.surface_text: On their displacement, they were in the first instance temporarily allotted agricultural land in Sultanwind.

facts.text: Petitioners allotted 38 standard acres and 13 units of agricultural land in Sultanwind in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to their original position in the village, they were allotted in the year 1949 a total area of 38 standard acres and 13 units of agricultural land therein.

facts.text: Director-General of Relief and Rehabilitation Additional Custodian ordered on January 7, 1950, allotment of 142 standard acres and 5 units out of 1,263 standard acres and 1 3/4 units of suburban land of Amritsar to allottees of Provincial Gardens.

anchor.surface_text: The Director-General of Relief and Rehabilitation  Additional Custodian  directed by an order dated January 7, 1950, that out of the 1,263 standard acres and 1 3/4 units of suburban land of Amritsar, 142 standard acres and 5 units were to be allotted to allottees of Provincial Gardens.

facts.text: This necessitated readjustment of allotments of suburban land of Sultanwind amongst various groups.

anchor.surface_text: This necessitated readjustment of allotments of the suburban land of Sultanwind amongst the various groups who had quasi-permanent allotment therein.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian, Amritsar proposed cancellation of petitioners' allotment by order dated July 31, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this readjustment which had to be carried out according to certain rules and instructions, the allotment of these five petitioners  as also of some others  was proposed for cancellation by the order of the Deputy Custodian, Amritsar, dated July 31, 1951.

facts.text: Proposal approved by Custodian Financial Commissioner, Relief and Rehabilitation on February 6, 1952, and allotment cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: This proposal was approved by the Custodian  Financial Commissioner, Relief and Rehabilitation  on February 6, 1952, and the allotment was cancelled.

facts.text: Proposal and order of cancellation passed without notice to petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The proposal and the order of cancellation are said to have been passed without numberice to the petitioners.

facts.text: Petitioners moved Custodian-General for revision under s. 27 of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved thereby they moved the Custodian-General of Evacuee Property for revision thereof under s. 27 of the Administration of Evancuee Property Act, 1950  XXXI of 1950 .

facts.text: Deputy Custodian-General dismissed revision on May 1, 1954, after hearing parties.

anchor.surface_text: This was dealt with by the Deputy Custodian-General who dismissed the same by a fairly elaborate order dated May 1, 1954, after hearing the parties.

facts.text: Petitioners filed application under Art. 32 of Constitution in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Jagannadhadas, J. This is an application under Art. 32 of the Constitution by the petitioners, Amar Singh and four others, in the following circumstances.

facts.text: Petitioners claim quasi-permanent allotment constitutes property rights under Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2).

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioners is that the allotment to them was on quasi-permanent basis and that, therefore, they have acquired certain rights in the lands which companystitute property.

facts.text: Cancellation orders violate petitioners' fundamental rights to property.

anchor.surface_text: They urge that the order of the Custodian canceling the allotment and that of the Deputy Custodian-General affirming the same are in violation of their fundamental rights to property under Arts. 19 1  f , 31 1  and 31 2  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioners are allottees on quasi-permanent basis; not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: That the petitioners are allottees of agricultural land on the basis of what has companye to be known as quasi-permanent allotment is number disputed.

facts.text: Cancellation under Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 and rules; not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is also number disputed that cancellation thereof was under the purported exercise of powers vested in the Custodian under certain provisions of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950  XXXI of 1950  and the rules framed thereunder

facts.text: Partition of India on August 15, 1947, accompanied by mass migrations.

anchor.surface_text: The Declaration of Independence and the partition of India into Pakistan and India on August 15, 1947, was accompanied by mass migrations of Non-Muslims from West Punjab to East Punjab

facts.text: About five million persons moved from each side.

anchor.surface_text: About five million persons are said to have moved from each side to the other.

facts.text: Displaced persons left about 67 lakh acres in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The displaced persons are said to have left in Pakistan lands of the extent of about 67 lakh acres.

facts.text: Evacuees left about 47 lakh acres in East Punjab and Pepsu.

anchor.surface_text: The evacuees sum to have left in East Punjab and Pepsu, lands of the extent of about 47 lakh acres.

facts.text: East Punjab Government Press Communique dated February 7, 1948 announced quasi-permanent allotment policy.

anchor.surface_text: This policy was announced by type Government of East Punjab in its Press Communique dated February 7, 1948, which is reproduced at pages 28 and 29 of the Resettlement Manual.

facts.text: Punjab Government notification No. 4892/S dated July 8, 1949 sets conditions for quasi-permanent allotments.

anchor.surface_text: In between these two Acts, numberification No. 4892/S dated July 8, 1949, was issued by the Punjab Government in exercise of the rule-making power vested in it under cls.  f  and  ff  of sub-s.  2  of s. 22 of East Punjab Act XIV of 1947 as amended in 1948.

facts.text: Court holds quasi-permanent allotment does not constitute property under Arts. 19(1)(f), 31.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, having given our best companysideration, we are unable to hold that the interest of a quasi-permanent allottee is property within the companycept of that word so as to attract the protection of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petition dismissed without costs.

anchor.surface_text: This petition is accordingly dismissed but, in the circumstances, without companyts.

issues.text: whether the rights of a quasi-permanent allottee constitute property within the meaning of the articles above referred to [Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2)]

anchor.surface_text: consideration are 1 whether the rights of a quasi-permanent allottee constitute property within the meaning of the articles above referred to, and 2 whether

issues.text: whether the orders of the Custodian and Deputy Custodian-General canceling the quasi-permanent allotment amount to violation of fundamental rights contemplated by the above articles [Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2)]

anchor.surface_text: the rights of a quasi-permanent allottee constitute property within the meaning of the articles above referred to, and 2 whether the orders of the Custodian and Deputy Custodian-General canceling the quasi-permanent allotment amount to violation fundamental rights contemplated by the above articles.

issues.text: whether the cancellation of quasi-permanent allotment constitutes deprivation of property without authority of law under Art. 31(1)

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the petitioners has urged that even if Arts 19(1)(f) and 31(2) are not applicable, the petitioners can invoke the protection of Art. 31(1) which says that no person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law.

arguments.claim: Quasi-permanent allotment constitutes property rights under Articles 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2), and cancellation violates these fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioners is that the allotment to them was on quasi-permanent basis and that, therefore, they have acquired certain rights in the lands which constitute property. They urge that the order of the Custodian canceling the allotment and that of the Deputy Custodian-General affirming the same are in violation of their fundamental rights to property under Arts. 19 1  f , 31 1  and 31 2  of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is the working out of the right of resumption or cancellation which was one of the incidents of the property. The cancellation by the Custodian author

arguments.court_reasoning: Interest is provisional, statutory, subject to cancellation, lacks ownership attributes like transferability

arguments.claim: Cancellation orders passed without notice to petitioners

anchor.surface_text: The proposal and the order of cancellation are said to have been passed without notice to the petitioners.

arguments.claim: Even if Articles 19(1)(f) and 31(2) inapplicable, cancellation deprives property without authority of law under Article 31(1)

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the petitioners has urged that even if Arts 19(1)(f) and 31(2) are not applicable, the petitioners can invoke the protection of Art. 31(1) which says that no person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to companystitute property, if it is meant to companyvey thereby that it is property which attracts the protection of fundamental rights under the Con

arguments.court_reasoning: Cancellation is authorised by the Act creating the rights, ss.28 and 46 bar challenge

arguments.claim: Quasi-permanent allottee rights do not constitute property under Articles 19(1)(f), 31(1), 31(2)

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, having given our best consideration, we are unable to hold that the interest of a quasi-permanent allottee is property within the concept of that word so as to attract the protection of fundamental rights.

arguments.claim: Evacuee property vests in Custodian under s.8 AEP Act 1950; Custodian has management powers including allotments under s.10, subject to variation/cancellation under s.12

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian has under s. 9 the power to take possession of all the evacuee property so vested in him. Section 10 enumerates the powers and duties of the Custodian ... under s. 12 1  to vary or cancel leases or allotments of evacuee property.

arguments.claim: Allotment defined as grant of right of use/occupation, originally temporary, quasi-permanent still not ownership

anchor.surface_text: allotment is defined as meaning the grant by a person duly authorised of a right of use or occupation of an immovable evacuee property to any other person but does not include a grant by way of a lease.

arguments.claim: Notification No.4892/S dt.7.8.1949 grants heritable rights of use/occupation subject to resumption/cancellation under cl.6 on administrative grounds

anchor.surface_text: notification No. 4892/S dated July 8, 1949, was issued by the Punjab Government ... This notification sets out the statement of conditions on which the Custodian could grant allotments of land vested in him.

arguments.claim: Rules must be read harmoniously with Act's cancellation powers under s.12 AEP 1950

anchor.surface_text: must, according to the ordinary rules of construction, be read so as to harmonise with the powers of cancellation under the Act itself.

arguments.claim: Subsequent rules (1950 Central, 1951 Punjab) expand but do not eliminate cancellation powers for resettlement, equity, management

anchor.surface_text: Rule 14 of Central Rules, 1950 ... The Custodian shall be competent to cancel or terminate any allotment ... for the implementation of resettlement schemes ... or in the interests of proper rehabilitation of displaced persons.

arguments.claim: 1952/1953 amendments to r.14 restrict but do not negate cancellation power; subject to s.12

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything contained in this rule, the Custodian ... shall not exercise the power of canceling any allotment of rural evacuee property on a quasi-permanent basis ... except in the following circumstances

arguments.claim: Under DPCRA 1954 s.10 allottee continues possession post-acquisition but s.19 allows variation/cancellation; r.102 specifies grounds

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 ... the displaced person shall, so long as the property remains vested ... continue in possession ... Section 19 ... the managing officer ... may cancel any allotment

arguments.claim: Quasi-permanent rights are statutory bundle lacking ownership: heritable/usable but non-transferable, improvable, subject to resumption for policy/rehabilitation

anchor.surface_text: The allottee is entitled to right of use and occupation ... benefit ... to his heirs ... subject to the fairly extensive powers of cancellation under the Act and rules

arguments.claim: Interest not disposable/acquirable by ordinary modes, so outside Art.19(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: Property, to fall within the scope of Art. 19 1  f , must be capable of being the subject-matter of acquisition and disposal. The interest of the quasi-permanent allottee ... is not capable of acquisition ... Nor is it capable of disposable

arguments.claim: Cancellation not acquisition/requisition under Art.31(2); merely revocation of use right

anchor.surface_text: Neither is the interest of the quasi-permanent allottee such as can be brought within the scope of Art. 31 2 . Article 31 2 ... contemplates acquisition or requisitioning and taking possession

arguments.claim: Cancellation by authority of law under AEP Act ss.28,46 finality and jurisdictional bar

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 provides that orders made under the above sections shall be final ... Section 46 bars the jurisdiction of the civil or revenue courts

arguments.claim: Deputy Custodian-General dismissal of revision after hearing parties valid

anchor.surface_text: This was dealt with by the Deputy Custodian-General who dismissed the same by a fairly elaborate order dated May 1, 1954, after hearing the parties.

holdings.text: the interest of a quasi-permanent allottee is [not] property within the concept of that word so as to attract the protection of fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, having given our best consideration, we are unable to hold that the interest of a quasi-permanent allottee is property within the concept of that word so as to attract the protection of fundamental rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory vesting in Custodian, definition of allotment as right of use/occupation, heritability but non-transferable, subject to wide cancellation powers under ss.10,12 AEP Act and rules; historical evolution shows provisional nature for rehabilitation; lacks ownership attributes like alienability

holdings.text: Interest of quasi-permanent allottee does not fall within Art. 19(1)(f) as not capable of acquisition or disposal

anchor.surface_text: Property, to fall within the scope of Art. 19(1)(f), must be capable of being the subject-matter of acquisition and disposal. The interest of the quasi-permanent allottee arises by statutory grant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.19(1)(f) protects property subject to ordinary market acquisition/disposal; quasi-permanent interest statutory, class-specific, non-transferable by sale/gift/mortgage/will

holdings.text: Interest of quasi-permanent allottee not within Art. 31(2) as no acquisition, requisitioning or taking possession

anchor.surface_text: Neither is the interest of the quasi-permanent allottee such as can be brought within the scope of Art. 31(2). Article 31(2) ... contemplates acquisition or requisitioning and taking possession

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.31(2) requires transfer of ownership/possession via acquisition; cancellation is revocation of provisional use right, not acquisition

holdings.text: Cancellation not deprivation without authority of law under Art.31(1); authorised by AEP Act creating the rights, ss.28/46 provide finality and jurisdictional bar

anchor.surface_text: What has happened, however, in this case is not deprivation of the property without the authority of law even assuming that the bundle of rights constituting such an interest in land is property. It is the working out of the right of resumption or cancellation which was one of the incidents of the property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming property, deprivation by statute (AEP Act ss.12,28,46) that created interest and mandates finality; no illegal usurpation

holdings.text: Orders of Custodian and Deputy Custodian-General do not violate Arts.19(1)(f),31(1),31(2); no fundamental right infringed

anchor.surface_text: For all the above reasons we are unable to hold that any fundamental right of the petitioners has been infringed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from h1-h4; interest not property, cancellation authorised

holdings.text: Quasi-permanent allottee interest does not constitute property attracting fundamental rights protection, disagreeing with Punjab High Court in Suraj Parkash Kapur

anchor.surface_text: But, with respect, we are unable to agree with the view expressed therein that a quasi-permanent allottee has such an interest in the land allotted to him as to constitute property, if it is meant to convey thereby that it is property which attracts the protection of fundamental rights under the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior analysis of statutes/rules/incidents prevails over lower court view

precedents.cited_proposition: The Land Resettlement Manual by Shri Tarlok Singh has the stamp of authority

anchor.surface_text: Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford  1880  5 App. Cas. 214

precedents.case_name: Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford
precedents.cited_proposition: Where a discretionary power is vested in a statutory authority to act in certain circumstances for the benefit of certain persons, the exercise of such power in favour of such a person where requisite conditions exist is obligatory and not optional

precedents.citation: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose 1954 S.C.R. 587, 673

anchor.surface_text: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose 1954 S.C.R. 587, 673

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: The word 'property' in Article 31(1) may be understood in a wider sense and deprivation of any individual right out of a bundle of rights constituting concrete property may be deprivation of property requiring authority of law
precedents.cited_holding: The word property as used in Article 31(1) may have been intended to be understood in a wider sense and deprivation of any individual right out of a bundle of rights constituting concrete property may be deprivation of property which would require the authority of law.

precedents.citation: Bishop of Oxfords case  1880  5 App. Cas. 214

anchor.surface_text: Bishop of Oxfords case  1880  5 App. Cas. 214

precedents.case_name: Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford
precedents.cited_proposition: Discretionary power to act for benefit of persons is obligatory where conditions exist

precedents.citation: Suraj Parkash Kapur v. The State of Punjab  1957  LIX P.L.R. 103

anchor.surface_text: Suraj Parkash Kapur v. The State of Punjab  1957  LIX P.L.R. 103

precedents.case_name: Suraj Parkash Kapur v. The State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: A quasi-permanent allottee has such an interest in the land allotted to him as to constitute property attracting protection of fundamental rights under the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This petition is accordingly dismissed but, in the circumstances, without costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Petition under Article 32 dismissed; no fundamental rights infringed
